meanings.definition: To divide into two branches or forks.
meanings.sent1: The river furcating into two smaller streams was a beautiful sight.
meanings.sent2: The tree furcated at the top, creating a lovely canopy.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally furcated my hair into two uneven sections while trying a new hairstyle.
meanings.sent4: The decision to furcate the project into two separate phases proved to be beneficial in the long run.
meanings.sent5: The lightning furcated across the sky, illuminating the dark clouds.

meanings.sent1: The road furcated into two paths, leading to different destinations.
meanings.sent2: The plant furcates as it grows, spreading its leaves in all directions.
meanings.sent3: The conversation furcated into multiple topics, making it hard to keep track.
meanings.sent4: Her thoughts furcated, considering both sides of the argument.
meanings.sent5: The cracks in the wall furcated like lightning, creating intricate patterns.

meanings.definition: Having a forked shape or appearance.
meanings.sent1: The furcating branches of the tree provided a shady spot to rest.
meanings.sent2: The furcating antlers of the deer were a majestic sight in the forest.
meanings.sent3: The furcating roads in the countryside added to the charm of the scenic drive.
meanings.sent4: The furcating lightning bolt in the painting gave it a dynamic and striking look.
meanings.sent5: The furcating cracks in the ice created a beautiful yet dangerous pattern.
